entry.title: Use GitLab + Terraform for managing your SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry environments
entry.content:
This blog post is inspired by this brilliant blog post and this dev.to article.

Instead of GitHub we will be using GitLab as our CI/CD platform of choice üöÄ There are some minor differences though in the process when we compare the setup with GitHub which I want to point out. I will also provide you with a ready to use GitLab CI/CD pipeline and that you can use. In addition I'll explain our idea how we want to manage our BTP environment based on our experience managing google cloud by following basic security best practices like always following the principle of least privilege for each user.

How does it work?

Here is a brief explanation of the GitLab CI/CD workflow using terraform.

  1. A GitLab CI/CD pipeline is triggered (e.g., by a git push or a manual action).
  2. The GitLab OIDC Provider generates a JWT token for the running pipeline job. This token is made available to the job as a predefined CI/CD variable, such as $OIDC_TOKEN.
  3. This JWT Bearer token is used by the SAP BTP & Cloud Foundry Terraform providers in the Terraform scripts for authentication
  4. The Terraform providers send this token to SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry (UAA). These platforms, configured to trust your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant, forward the token to it for validation.
  5. The SAP Cloud Identity Service validates the JWT's signature against the public keys (JWKS) of your GitLab instance's OIDC provider.
  6. If the token is successfully validated (based on the Enriched Token Claims settings, a user is found), the Terraform providers are authenticated and with the "mapped" user all subsequent calls will be made with this users authorization.

1. Create a new GitLab project

Create a new blank GitLab Project. The relevant content will be added later

2. Setup GitLab as OIDC provider in your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant

First we need to setup GitLab.com as OIDC identity providers in the SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant.

  1. Login to your CIS tenant as admin.
  2. Create a new user group for all your GitLab users e.g. Name: GitLab CI/CD
  3. Go to 'Identity Providers' ‚Üí 'Corporate Identity Providers' ‚Üí Click '+ Create'.
  4. Use gitlab.com as provider name, select OpenID Connect Compliant as provider type. Click create
  5. Click on OpenID Connect Configuration. The Discovery URL for gitlab.com is https://gitlab.com/.well-known/openid-configuration 
  6. Now we also need a valid client for the authentication. Such an application has to be created in gitlab itself.
  7. Login to gitlab. Open a group or project that you want to use for btp deployments. In the menu select Settings -> Applications.
  8. Create a new application, give it a speaking name e.g. SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant <yourTenantId>, as Callback use https://<your-tenant>.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/callback, and select openid as Scope.
  9. Store the client id and client secret somewhere safe if needed.
  10. Enter the client id and client secret in the OpenID Connect Configuration.
  11. Add openid as scope and then save the configuration.
  12. Configure the token to user mapping in section Enriched Token Claims.
    Depending on your setup you need to define how you want to "identify" your users. You can find a list of supported claims from GitLab here
    Example:
    Claim: NameId
    Value: ${project_id}-${environment}@gitlab.com
  13. Follow the additional steps of the blog (Configure 'Identity Federation' to Restrict the GitHub IdP to GitHub CI/CD Users Only, Step 1.4)

Now just like in the blog we create a new user that follows our Enriched Token Claims format e.g. <gitlabProjectId>-prod@gitlab.com. Assign the user to the GitLab CI/CD group etc.

3. Maintain newly created user in SAP BTP with appropriate role

With the current setup the authentication would already work with the btp and cf providers but are still lacking the appropriate authorization for the new user.

Depending on the level of access (Globalaccount vs Subaccount) you need to assign the user manually and assign the role you need.

HINT: For some operations on subaccount level you might still need specific roles on global account level e.g. for reading assigned service plans


4 Setup the CI/CD pipeline + terraform code

Now we finally come to the fun part üòÖ

Our basic folder structure looks like this:

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitlab-ci.yml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ terraform
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ modules
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ btp
    ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
    ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outputs.tf
    ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf
    ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ versions.tf
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ cloud_foundry
    ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
    ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outputs.tf
    ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf
    ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ versions.tf
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ prod
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .terraform.lock.hcl
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.tf
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ variables.tf
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ versions.tf

We have a terraform folder, which contains all our terraform code. Inside the terraform folder we have a modules folder. One for btp and another one for cloud foundry. All resources that should be deployed in the specific environment will be described there.

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the btp folder

Spoiler
btp folder
main.tf
data "btp_subaccount" "subaccount" {
  id = var.subaccount_id
}

resource "random_uuid" "uuid" {}

locals {
  subaccount_name      = "${var.subaccount_stage} ${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}"
  subaccount_subdomain = join("-", [lower(replace("${var.subaccount_stage}-${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}", " ", "-")), random_uuid.uuid.result])
}

resource "btp_subaccount_environment_instance" "cloudfoundry" {
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  name             = "${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name} ${var.subaccount_stage}"
  environment_type = "cloudfoundry"
  service_name     = "cloudfoundry"
  plan_name        = "standard"

  parameters = jsonencode({
    instance_name = local.subaccount_subdomain
  })
}
‚Äã

variables.tf

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}

outputs.tf


output "cf_api_url" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["API Endpoint"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry API URL"
}

output "cf_org_id" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["Org ID"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
}

versions.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
  }
}

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the cloud foundry folder

 

Spoiler
variables.tf
variable "cf_org_id" {
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
‚Äã

main.tf

Spoiler
resource "cloudfoundry_space" "space" {
name = var.subaccount_stage
org = var.cf_org_id
}

data "cloudfoundry_service_plan" "html5_apps_repo_plan_cf" {
service_offering_name = "html5-apps-repo"
name = "app-host"
}

resource "cloudfoundry_service_instance" "html5_repo" {
name = "html5-repo-${var.subaccount_stage}"
space = cloudfoundry_space.space.id
service_plan = data.cloudfoundry_service_plan.html5_apps_repo_plan_cf.id
type = "managed"
}
outputs.tf is empty
versions.tf
terraform {
  required_providers {
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
}
‚Äã

And here is the code that will be accessed from our ci/cd pipeline. Many projects of us have different environments/stages (dev/qas/prod). There for we manage the main code in modules with all the ressources that will be deployed in each environment.

The environment/stages folders (dev,qas,prod) then basically just use the defined modules with some variables. This ensures that each environment contains the same resources (or differ a little bit depending on requirements e.g. a prod database setup might be different compared to dev/qas database setup).

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the prod folder.

 

Spoiler
variables.tf (all variable values are defined in the GitLab UI)
variable "globalaccount" {
  description = "The name of the global account in SAP BTP."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "idp_origin_key" {
  description = "The origin key for the Identity Provider (IDP)."
  type        = string
}
variable "cf_region" {
  description = "The region for the Cloud Foundry environment."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
‚Äã

providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

versions.tf (backend "http" {} is enough to manage the terraform state in GitLab)

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
  backend "http" {}
}
main.tf
module "btp" {
  source           = "../modules/btp"
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}

module "cloud_foundry" {
  source           = "../modules/cloud_foundry"
  cf_org_id        = module.btp.cf_org_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}
‚Äã

 

 

 

4.1 GitLab CI/CD Pipeline

This is where the ü™Ñ magic happens. Let's have a look at the pipeline definition ( .gitlab-ci.yml file ).

Hint: In our environment we use GitLab CI/CD components. This avoids copy and pasting pipeline definitions and allows central maintenance including versioning and testing.

variables:
    TF_ROOT: $CI_PROJECT_DIR/terraform/$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_STATE_NAME: $CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_VERSION: "1.12.2"

stages:
    - terraform prepare
    - terraform check
    - terraform plan
    - terraform apply

.job_template:
    image:
        name: hashicorp/terraform:$TF_VERSION
        entrypoint: [""]
    before_script:
        - cd $TF_ROOT
    variables:
        TF_HTTP_ADDRESS: "${CI_API_V4_URL}/projects/${CI_PROJECT_ID}/terraform/state/${TF_STATE_NAME}"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_METHOD: "POST"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_METHOD: "DELETE"
        TF_HTTP_RETRY_WAIT_MIN: "5"
        TF_HTTP_USERNAME: "gitlab-ci-token"
        TF_HTTP_PASSWORD: ${CI_JOB_TOKEN}
        TF_IN_AUTOMATION: "true"
    cache:
        key: "$CI_PROJECT_ID-$CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME"
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/.terraform"
        policy: pull
    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

"terraform prepare":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    cache:
        policy: push
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform validate
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform tf lint":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    image:
        name: ghcr.io/terraform-linters/tflint:v0.58.1
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - tflint --init
        - tflint --recursive

"terraform tf fmt":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform fmt -recursive -check

"terraform plan":
    stage: terraform plan
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform plan -input=false -out="plan.cache"
        - apk --no-cache add jq
        - terraform show -json "plan.cache" | jq -r "( [.resource_changes[]?.change.actions?] | flatten) | { \"create\":(map(select(.==\"create\")) | length), \"update\":(map(select(.==\"update\")) | length), \"delete\":(map(select(.==\"delete\")) | length) }" > plan.json
    artifacts:
        name: plan
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/plan.cache"
        reports:
            terraform:
                - "$TF_ROOT/plan.json"
    needs:
        - "terraform prepare"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform apply":
    stage: terraform apply
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: start
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform apply -input=false "plan.cache"
    rules:
        - if: "$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == $CI_DEFAULT_BRANCH"
          when: manual
    needs:
        - "terraform plan"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    when: manual
    allow_failure: false

If you feel overwhelmed, that's ok üòÖ I try to explain the most important parts.

We are using the official terraform image therefore we have to do some standard customization in the .job_template by setting some terraform variables for managing the state hosted on GitLab.

But most important is the definition of our token:

    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

The variable $OIDC_TOKEN is a predefined, short-lived JWT token that GitLab automatically generates for authenticating with OIDC providers. This is a secure method that avoids storing static secrets. In order to use it with our Cloud Identity Service we need to adjust the aud property (audience) and use the URL of our Cloud Identity Service Tenant.

Now all we need to take care of assigning the value of the OIDC_TOKEN to the environment variables needed by the btp and cloud foundry terraform providers. We do this on the job level and assign the value of the OIDC token to the environment variables read by the terraform providers:

    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN

4.3 Terraform provider setup

Now we "only" need to setup the terraform providers for btp and cloud foundry to ensure that they use the JWT token for authentication. This is done in terraform/prod/providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

4.4 Define Terraform Variables for prod environment in GitLab

The last step is to maintain the needed variables for the prod environment in GitLab.

Open your project on GitLab and go to Settings -> CI/CD -> Variables

Now you can maintain all needed terraform variables. Important if to always prefix them with TF_VAR_variable_name.

By making use of the environment and managing the main resources inside modules, are able to deploy all needed environments/stages per project by using just one GitLab project üöÄ.

This is the complete setup. Feel free to use it, adjust it, improve it, ... . I hope you learned something today and can benefit from the approach I am demonstrating here.

Outlook to our future approach

We want to follow our design principle that we have already successfully deployed in Google Cloud:

  • One central landing zone project which contains the overall global btp landscape and manages global trust, directories and subaccounts
    • The subaccount module will not only create the subaccount but also the "technical user" needed for the GitLab integration by utilizing the SAP Cloud Identity Provider Terraform Provider and assign this user to the appropriate role
    • In google cloud the creator of the project (=subaccount in btp), automatically became the owner of the project (full access). At the end of the project creation we always removed the landscaper user from the owner role to ensure that only the newly created project technical user is able to deploy ressources inside the project.
      We will try to setup the same approach in BTP. The landscape user should not be able to create any additional ressources inside a subaccount after the subaccount setup. This is the responsibility of the team working on the new project inside the subaccount.
  • Almost all platform users will only have viewer access to ensure that nobody does any changes by "accident". The terraform workflow sometimes takes a little longer compared to just a few clicks, but IaC brings you all the benefits compared to ClickOps
  • Every new BTP project will have one GitLab project for maintaining the infrastructure but also everything else needed for the project.
    • Right now we are migrating a CAP app from Google Cloud to SAP BTP (forced by the new license üôÑ)
    • The terraform code and the CAP source code are all managed in the same GitLab Project. One team member can take of provisioning the infrastructure, while another team member is adapting the CAP code. CAP app deployment will then also be done using the GitLab CI/CD pipeline (and of course automated tests upfront to ensure we did not break anything).

Questions?

Feel free to leave a comment or contact me directly here or via LinkedIn.

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508
entry.content:
SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2508

With the launch of the new release 2508, this blog post delivers an in-depth overview of the newest features and improvements. The release has been available since August 16th, replacing the previous 2505 release. The highlights of the current release include: Support of CDS Table Entities as active persistence in RAP, SAP Fiori-based Multi-Dimensional Reporting or the new software delivery option for partners the "Add-On Product". 

The list of all new features can be found on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment page

All new AI features are summarized here.

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  • Creation of Behavior Definition for CDS Table Entities (see Table Entities and Creating Data Definitions)
  • New Icons for Fiori User Interface Editors (details)
  • Extensions to the Class and Interface: C1 Consistency and Compatibility Checks, the ATC checks API Release: Consistency of Released APIs and API Release: Compatibility of Released APIs now check for consistency and compatibility about BDEF-derived types in released classes and interfaces
  • ADT Debugger Comparison Tool for Internal Tables (details)
  • Enrichment in the Element Information Popup, you can now search for substrings within the structured display of the Element Information popup (see Editing ABAP Source Code and Analyzing CDS Objects)
  • Learning from the Key Bindings Toolbar and Highlighting Ghost Text at Keyword Completion In-Line (see Concepts: Keyword Completion and Tasks: Keyword Completion)
  • Display of Copyright Statement for ABAP Development Objects in Properties View
  • HTTP-based ADT Links for Form-Based Objects, until now, the HTTP-link support was available only for the source-code-based ABAP objects 
  • RAP Business Objects Test Double Framework: Auto-Fill CID Support for Modify EML Statement (details)
  • Working with Forms, you can create form templates using Adobe LiveCycle Designer directly in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. Form Templates can be retrieved during runtime via the class CL_FP_FORM_READER (details)
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Checks, you can now create and modify the consistency checks you want to perform on your business documents
  • Working with Electronic Document Consistency Representation Types, you can create and modify representation types for your business documents based on their source location. Configure these representation types within the Electronic Document Consistency framework to ensure consistency

Core Data Services

  • New CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2: Business Event Data v2, C_BUSEVTLOGACTIVITYDEX: Business Event Activity,  C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3: Business Event Header Data (v3)
  • Deprecated CDS Views in Business Event Logging: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_2 (Business Event Header Data (v2) Use the following successor: C_BUSEVTLOGEVENTDEX_3 and C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPAYLOADJSONDEX (Business Event Data): Use the following successor: C_BUEVLGEVTFULLPYLDJSONDEX_2
  • CDS Hierarchy Generation Wizard, the wizard will derive potential hierarchy nodes already from the start (on the master data view) and guide you through the creation process

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

  • Collaborative Draft, you can now add collaborative capabilities to your business object. The collaborative draft allows multiple users to work concurrently on the same draft instance (details)
  • Cross-BO Transactional Enablement, cross-BO scenarios can now be transactionally enabled by defining a cross-BO context for the respective BDEFs (see RAP-Operations for Associations and RAP-with Cross Associations and RAP-AssocImplType)
  • RAP Factory Actions, they now return the http status 201 instead of 200 in case of a successful OData V4 response

SAP Fiori

  • Fiori-Based Multi-Dimensional Reporting ‚Äì Cloud-Compliant, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, but simple list reporting doesn‚Äôt satisfy your needs? Instead, you already built an analytical model with the new embedded analytics capabilities of the developer extensibility and now want to unleash its full potential? In that case, we have the right solution for you: Without writing a single line of additional code, you can simply expose your model in a full-fledged analytical application with a modern Fiori-based UI and real multi-dimensional ‚Äúslicing & dicing‚Äù capabilities
  • Fiori-Based Multi-Report Applications, you need to quickly build an analytical Fiori application, that puts multiple analytical queries into one context in a single UI? All you need to do is to provide the queries, bundle them in an InA Service and you are good to just start the brand new "Review Booklet Application" wizard to generate the application. Afterwards, you can refine the configuration of your Review Booklet in an easy to use Fiori UI
  • Fiori UIs for Communication Management Change History, it is now possible to view the communication management change history in Fiori UIs
  • Change Document Reuse UI, you can embed a reuse UI in your RAP OData V4 Fiori application (details)

Business Configuration 

  • Reduce Footprint with the existing RAP generator for business configuration maintenance objects, you can easily generate all development objects that are required for a configuration object. Since the number of objects is still quite large, optimizations in the RAP programming model have been implemented that reduce the number of required development objects and make them easier for a developer to manage 

Security

  • Business User Authentication, option for configuring secondary signing certificates, currently only basic authentication is supported as authentication for SMTP outbound communication. With this feature, also the OAuth Client Credential Grant will be supported

Business Events

  • Activate Business Event Logging, with this release, there are changes to the behavior of the configuration object. The option to select the logging of all data has been removed. By default, when you enable logging of data, all business event data will be recorded (details)
  • View Object Relationships, with this feature, you can view inbound and outbound relationships for logged objects in business event logging. You can also navigate across object components (details)
  • Log RAP-based C1 events, this feature enables the logging of C1-released, RAP-based events for local consumption (details)
  • Grouping Events as Activities, with this release, events of the same type and object occurring in the same session are grouped as activities. Sequences in the application Display Business Events by Objects are displayed according to activities. A new CDS view is also released to retrieve activity details. An activity is an action performed by a user or the system that initiates an event in the system (details) 
  • Expose Extensibility Status in Open Resource Discovery Document for Business Events, the Open Resource Discovery document for business events now exposes the extensibility status (details)
  • Success Log For Processed Events, it is now possible to configure a log for successfully processed events
  • Source Event Filter, you can now restrict the sending of events by defining filters for event topics. These filters can now also be created directly for event payload properties

Integration

  • Code Snippet in SOAP Service Consumption Model changed, the updated service consumption model improves the instantiation of consumer proxies and optimizes receiver determination through logical ports (details)

  • You can build and manage your own application interfaces in ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT) with the SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF). Due to the lack of ADT for AIF, the development objects for asynchronous integrations (event consumption model and asynchronous SOAP services) currently generate their corresponding AIF interfaces with default monitoring settings automatically. With new AIF development capabilities in ADT, these AIF interfaces can be customized. Custom AIF interfaces can also be created, for monitoring the background processing framework (bgPF) in ABAP Cloud, for example
  • The ABAP HTTP client and server now support server-sent events (SSE). Which allows a server to send parts of the body of the response to the client without the client having to actively request them. After being sent by the server, the client can fetch them as they become available (details)

Data Integration

  • Outbound SQL via CDS External Entities, the ADT generation wizard allows you to develop outbound SQL scenarios more efficiently by generating the required CDS external entities based on an imported CSN definition of the remote SQL API
  • SQL Service, INSERT and DELETE on Writable CDS View Entities, in data integration scenarios, users can access data in an ABAP system from an external consumer, using the SQL service and the ODBC driver for ABAP. So far, users can query data in exposed CDS view entities, and this was a read-only scenario, where SELECT statements could be used. Now, the SQL service can also be used to change data in exposed writable CDS view entities using INSERT and DELETE statements. Use cases for INSERT and DELETE in such a data integration scenario include: full replication of data from another system into the ABAP system or bringing data into staging tables that will be later used for your custom ABAP coding (details)

Reuse Services

  • Print Queue Administrator Integration, you can now create and delete print queues directly using APIs without the need to enter the Maintain Print Queues app. You can do so using the communication scenario SAP_COM_0A86 (details)

Background Processing Framework

  • Background processing is very important for business applications. A lot of logic can be executed asynchronously to improve performance. In scenarios where changes of the current LUW are to be communicated remotely, the asynchronous execution is even mandatory to be compliant with the SAP LUW (due to implicit database commits). entry.title: DSP SQL Navigator ‚Äì Stop copy pasting URLs!
entry.content:
I have been working with SAP Datasphere since 2019, back when it was still called SAP Data Warehouse Cloud (DWC). Obviously I have built my fair share of SQL views, and have been analyzing SQL views even more. That means a lot of jumping from one SQL view to another, which I do through copy-pasting the URL that I am currently on and changing it to the view I want to jump to. I must have copy-pasted hours on end since 2019 on a daily basis. But that is now behind me, and I will make sure you don‚Äôt have to anymore as well!

So like I wrote in the introduction, what I do to jump from one SQL view, to the view that lies beneath it is:

  • Copy the current URL
  • Copy the view name I want to jump into
  • Overwrite the last part of the URL with this view name.

I have always thought there must be a faster way to do this. With the upcoming of ‚Äúvibe-coding‚Äù and tools like Cursor and Claude Code, I finally tried to make my day a lot easier, by trying to code a browser extension.

Together with Claude I wrote a Product Requirement Document (PRD) and started working on the project together with Claude Code. Within a few hours the first useful version of the browser extension could be imported into my browser, and just a few hours later I had a polished version that I am now ready to share with you!

The plugin basically automated my old workflow. When you are in a SQL view and want to jump to the SQL view underneath that one, you simply select the view you want to jump to and press your hotkey and it open a new browser tab and open up that view for you!

Want to try it out? Basically all you have to do is download the plugin browser from the Google Web Store through this link. Then you have to assign a hotkey via the settings of the plugin and it works! You can also first check the demo if you want in this Youtube movie, where I show off the process! 

I am currently still working on the feature to jump to a view that is shared from another space, and will bring a new version of the plugin as soon as possible. If you have any questions please feel free to reach out to me!

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you‚Äôve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA , SAP Analytics Cloud ,  Artificial Intelligence , SAP Business Technology Platform , within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor‚Äôs or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2‚Äì3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP‚Äôs mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via üëâ  SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP‚Äôs social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

entry.title: SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
entry.content:
The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is your compass towards architecting, developing, and operating solutions on SAP BTP. It is the central access point for decision guides, reference architectures, methodologies, recommendations and DevOps principles. IT guides developers, administrators, architects, and partners with best practices along their journey.

This blog post focuses on the SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide, which is a guided path for application development on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). As part of our blog series, we are diving into several topic areas to best help you navigate the framework. Refer to our first blog post for an introduction to the BTP Guidance Framework.

Who is the SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide for?

The SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide is embedded into the SAP BTP Guidance Framework and is dedicated to developers, architects, development project leads, and SAP partners. The guide supports each role to plan the application architecture, define the correct methodologies and tools, and select the right services. SAP partners can additionally use the guide to set up SAP BTP for developing and running applications and services for their customers.

What is it about?

The SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide explains the building blocks for developing, delivering, and running business applications following the design-led development phases. As development projects for business applications have similar characteristics, this guide condenses best practices and technologies that can be safely recommended to you. The goal of the guide is to support you along the development process as a standardized development guidance and to drive developer efficiency.

 

 

ExploreIdentify the business opportunity and set up the roles and responsibilities in your team.

DeliverDevelop your application by following the recommendations for the respective programming model (CAP & ABAP Cloud), programming languages, development tools and consider aspects such as multitenancy, security, extensibility and others.
Run & Scale Get constant feedback from your users, optimize the application based on their feedback, and operate the application using the services and capabilities SAP BTP offers.

About Me

Hare Krishna üôè I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

üìùIntroduction

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business environment, enterprises are under constant pressure to reduce costs üí∞, accelerate innovation üöÄ, and stay agile ‚ö°. Many organizations still run on-premise SAP HANA üóÑÔ∏è or ECC systems üè¢, which can limit scalability, slow analytics üìä, and increase IT overhead üõ†Ô∏è.

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud ‚òÅÔ∏è offers a solution: a cloud-native, scalable, and intelligent platform ü§ñ that not only modernizes your database but also unlocks new opportunities for business growth üìà, advanced analytics üìä, and AI-driven insights ü§ñ.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success üåü.

1. Why Businesses Should Care About Migration

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • üí∏Rising infrastructure and data center costs

  • üìâDifficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

  • ‚ö°Pressure to innovate with real-time analytics and machine learning

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database upgrade ‚Äî it is a strategic enabler for business transformation:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èElastic scalability ‚Üí pay only for what you use

  • üí∞Lower TCO ‚Üí no hardware refresh, no patching overhead

  • ü§ñBuilt-in innovation ‚Üí multi-model (graph, JSON, geospatial), ML integration, Datasphere

  • üõ°Ô∏è Cloud-grade resilience ‚Üí HA, backups, encryption built in

üëâFor enterprises planning RISE with SAP, migration is often a key milestone. For GROW with SAP customers, HANA Cloud is already the default foundation.

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • üè¨High traffic spikes during Black Friday, festive sales, and seasonal launches

  • üíæHardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

  • üìäAnalytics delays slowed decision-making for inventory replenishment, pricing, and promotions

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ‚òÅÔ∏èScale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • üìäIntegrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • üí∞Reduce infrastructure costs by 25‚Äì30% while improving system performance

  • üõíOptimize promotional planning and inventory allocation by leveraging faster analytics on HANA Cloud

üëâResult: Smooth operations during peak shopping periods, lower costs, faster reporting, and improved customer satisfaction ‚Äî all while creating a foundation for a future move to S/4HANA Cloud.

3.üõ†Ô∏è‚ö° Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud can be complex, but SAP provides self-service migration tools to simplify the process, reduce risk, and speed up implementation.

1Ô∏è‚É£Assessment & Planning

  • üõ†Ô∏è Review current HANA workloads, database size, and custom code.

  • üìùDecide whether to migrate using sidecar (DB only) or full migration.

  • üîíMap compliance, security, and network requirements.

  • üìäIdentify business processes to migrate first (e.g., analytics sandbox or critical ERP data).

üëâReference: SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

2Ô∏è‚É£Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Cockpit / DMO (Database Migration Option):

  • üõ†Ô∏è Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ‚ö°Supports multiple migration scenarios:

  • üîÑAutomated delta replication: Keeps source and target databases in sync until cutover.

entry.title: UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
After the announcement on July 1st regarding the availability of SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the reaction was of great excitement and interest in learning more about the next steps especially about the tenant rewiring option to move existing tenants to SAP BDC. If you missed the announcement, you could read it here: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud - SAP Community

The objective of this blog is to share with you the latest information about the tenant rewiring and what it involves.

First, what does it mean for an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud to be rewired?

A tenant rewiring does not mean artefacts or data migration, it mainly refers to the consumption approach (from a commercial model perspective) of these services, and to the customer facing tool to manage the tenant lifecycles (via SAP for Me).  The tenant itself will remain the same, and the URL of the current tenants will not change either. In addition, there are no additional charges for rewiring an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud tenant to SAP BDC.

Second, how will the tenant rewiring work?

There are two paths for customers when it comes to how the tenant rewiring will work.

Customers may have started their consumption of SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via one of the following consumption models:

  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned and managed by SAP
  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned self-service by customers via the customers SAP BTP Global Accounts.

The tenant rewiring tool will support both models; however, the way the process is triggered will be different.

For the SAP-managed / provisioned tenants, the tenant rewiring will be initiated automatically as soon as you update your subscription with SAP (via your SAP account team) to move your subscription from the standalone product subscription to the SAP BDC subscription. This means that the tenant rewiring will be initiated as part of your subscription change request, and the tenant will automatically move to SAP BDC.

When you have a new subscription to SAP BDC, you will receive an email notification from SAP to log into your SAP for Me account. You will need to activate your BDC cockpit in your appropriate data center. If these steps are done prior to the tenant rewiring process, you will be able to see the rewired tenants in your BDC formation as soon as the process is completed.

NOTE: You must use the same hyperscaler and the same data center for your BDC cockpit as your current standalone subscription. The tenant rewiring tool does not migrate tenants between hyperscalers or data centers.

It is important to mention that the tenant will be available for your end users during the process and there is no tenant downtime required by the tenant rewiring tool.

For the tenants that are provisioned self-service via the customers SAP BTP Global Account, your admin will be able to initiate the tenant rewiring directly via the BTP Global Account, also self-service. The only pre-condition required is that a BDC subscription must pre-exist before triggering the tenant rewiring process to move the tenant to SAP BDC.

The steps are as follows:

  • BTP Admin goes in the BTP Global Account / BTP cockpit and updates the BTP Service instance related to the tenant
  • The request is received by SAP and the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to BDC
  • Login to SAP for Me and, login to BDC, go to the resources tab where you will be able to find the rewired tenants under ‚Äúbdc-rewired‚Äù resource group.
  • Once the rewiring is completed, the tenant will be visible in BDC

Overall, the tenants are preserved and now will be consumed via SAP BDC.

For more information and step-by-step, visit the tenant rewiring documentation.

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

What‚Äôs New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Reference Architecture for Event-Driven Application in Missing Part Fulfilment Busine
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of Industry 4.0, the ability to respond to real-time events in industrial production is crucial for operational efficiency. This blog outlines a proof of concept (PoC) that demonstrates how Airbus leveraged SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build Process Automation (BPA), and Events-to-Business Actions Framework to automate and orchestrate the missing part fulfillment process within production operations. The solution leverages an event-driven architecture to automate business processes based on missing part fulfillment in real-time.

This architecture is highly repeatable and can be applied to a wide range of SAP scenarios such as plant maintenance, purchase requisitions, inventory updates, and more, making it a valuable reference for enterprises looking to scale event-driven integrations. 

Engagement

The outcome described in this article was facilitated by custom adaptation of the Events-to-Business-Actions Framework by Airbus and was supported by SAP OCTO Team under PVN Pavankumar

Business Scenario : Missing Part Fulfilment in Production

The use case centres on streamlining the missing part fulfilment process within Airbus production operations. It begins when a missing part is detected for a work order reservation in the SAP ECC backend, which supports day-to-day production activities. From that initial identification, the process continues all the way through to the confirmation of the work order operation.

Throughout this journey, the workflow leverages an event-driven architecture (EDA) to track progress in real time, integrating seamlessly with backend systems. SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) orchestrates collaboration between all involved actors by sending out forms and notifications, gathering approvals, and automating decisions based on predefined business rules. Additionally, the PoC highlights the real-time monitoring and dashboarding features of SAP Build Process Automation, ensuring end-to-end visibility across the process.

This PoC showcases how we made that happen. 

Solution Architecture

Below is the architecture diagram representing the technical landscape for the missing part fulfilment process.

Figure 1: End-to-end architecture of the Airbus missing part fulfillment solution using SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, E2B Framework, and custom Node.js applications.

Technical Implementation 

This architecture leverages key components across SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, and custom applications to create a robust event-to-action pipeline: The Solution Architecture is illustrated in Figure 1, and the important components along with their connectivity are explained below:

-> Business events are triggered:
Different actors interact with the SAP backend (supporting production operations). Transactions such as work order reservations, purchase orders, or outbound deliveries generate relevant business events.

-> Events are routed to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM):
These events are sent to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh‚Äîeither directly or via Solace event brokers in Airbus Private Cloud, especially if events need to be shared with other platforms.

->  Event-specific queues manage the flow:
Within SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, specific queues collect events related to predefined topics, pushing them into the Events to Business Actions (E2B) framework.

->  Business logic and workflows are triggered:
E2B calls SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) APIs to:

  • Apply decision rules and determine what business action should occur based on the event payload,
  • Launch new workflow instances,
  • Update waiting tasks on running workflows,
  • Push events to visibility scenarios for process monitoring.

->  Backend queries for richer context:
E2B also calls backend APIs to fetch more information related to business objects‚Äîsuch as:

  • Details of a reservation linked to a purchase order,
  • The specific station tied to a work order reservation,
  • The list of actors involved, leveraging Responsibility Management in SAP S/4HANA based on attributes like station.

->  Traceability with PartsNow:
PartsNow, is a custom SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP,Node.js) application, used to persist the relationship between workflow instance IDs and related work order reservation IDs. E2B registers new workflow instances and can retrieve instance details as needed via PartsNow APIs.

->  Unified user experience in SAP Build Workzone:
SAP Build Workzone serves as the entry point for business actors, providing:

  • My Inbox: For completing tasks such as form fills or approvals,
  • My Processes: For real-time workflow monitoring,
  • Process Visibility Dashboard: To track KPIs and process efficiency,
  • Studio Home: Where process specialists can manage BPA decision rules.

->  Automated notifications and integration points:
Finally, SAP BPA calls remote APIs to:

  • Inform the PartsNow app about workflow instance completion,
  • Send email notifications to relevant actors via an SMTP server.

 

Developer Insights

As a developer building this PoC, a few key learnings stand out:

  • Loose coupling using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh and queues ensures resiliency and scalability.
  • Decision capability in SAP Build Process Automation allowed us to externalize complex logic from the app code, making it easier to maintain and extend.
  • Using SAP BTP Destinations and Service Bindings helped standardize secure backend access across environments.

Deployment Steps

Follow this GitHub documentation for detailed steps for configuration and deployment.

 

Closing Remarks

We hope this blog has inspired new ideas for applying event-driven automation to your own business processes.

Refer to SAP Architecture Centre and Events-to-Business-Actions Framework Repository for implementation details. 

Thanks to colleagues from SAP OCTO Team Praveen Kumar Padegal and Swati Maste for their support.

Meeting Developers Where They Are

To that end, I‚Äôm excited to share that SAP is introducing Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to boost development with the following technologies:

  2. SAP Fiori Elements 
  3. SAPUI5 

By adopting these new MCP standards, developers can seamlessly extend SAP‚Äôs development capabilities into multiple environments, ensuring flexibility and choice. SAP Build now enhances popular IDEs and AI coding assistants such as Cursor, Windsurf, Github Copilot, Cline and Claude Code.

We are also excited to share that the MCP Servers are being released as an open-source projects, licensed under the Apache-2.0 license. This marks another step in our commitment to openness and community-driven innovation. Learn more about Open Source at SAP.

MCP is an emerging open standard that allows AI models and tools to interact in a structured, secure, and consistent way. MCP acts as a universal bridge between an AI coding assistant with an LLM and external tools, data, and workflows ‚Äî so the model can seamlessly fetch context, take actions, and deliver more accurate, useful results. MCP gives developers the ability to integrate their tools with the broader AI ecosystem while receiving the right assistance, at the right time, without switching contexts.

Whether you‚Äôre generating backend services, UIs, or business logic, you can rely on the same quality, structure, and compliance.

Scaling AI Agents with SAP Expertise

One of the most powerful aspects of MCP adoption is the ability to upscale AI agent chat capabilities with deep SAP application development expertise. This means that AI copilots and agents can go beyond generic code suggestions to provide context-aware, SAP-specific guidance. Whether you are working with Vibe Coding tools on the web or coding directly in your IDE of choice, MCP brings value to everyone ‚Äî from casual and junior developers to senior professionals. It enables you to build enterprise-grade SAP applications with confidence, while seamlessly combining AI-driven assistance with SAP‚Äôs trusted frameworks, best practices, and tooling to maximize productivity.

 

Looking Ahead

These are exciting times to be a developer. The combination of AI and open standards like MCP is rewriting the rules of software development. At SAP, we are committed to keeping our developer community at the forefront of innovation. By investing in AI-powered tools and standards, we ensure that you‚Äîour developers‚Äîhave everything you need to build, scale, and innovate with confidence. üöÄ

Organizations around the world are migrating their databases to the cloud, striving to increase operational efficiency, performance, and scalability while reducing costs. But not all databases are created equal.

SAP HANA Cloud is a cloud-native, in-memory database that delivers high performance, scalability, and powerful analytics. It lets you store, process, and query various types of data and models in a single system. Developers can build and deploy intelligent applications, rapidly and at scale. These are just a few of the reasons why so many companies have moved to SAP HANA Cloud.

The value is clear. In a recent study,[1]  IDC found that large enterprises could realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud. This benefit equates to $820,000 per SAP HANA Cloud database per year, with a three-year ROI of 352%. Isn‚Äôt that impressive?

In each blog, I‚Äôll review some of the key features and capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud and explore how each one can help your organization realize critical business value. Let‚Äôs get started.

Multi-model engines

No enterprise relies on only one type of data. Depending on your business, you may be using relational, geospatial, graph, JSON, and vector data, for example. This data can be structured, semi-structured, or unstructured, including text and multimedia content. Some organizations funnel data into single-purpose databases that handle only certain data types. SAP HANA Cloud handles diverse workloads within a unified system‚Äîprocessing relational, geospatial, knowledge graph, time series, and vector data for AI applications. This ability to support multi-modal AI, where systems comprehend and process information from various data types, adds versatility. Application developers can integrate diverse data sources into a single application with ease and users can query and blend diverse data types intuitively. Multi-modal AI also reduces the need for complex ETL processes between systems.

The multi-model capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud deliver value by improving productivity. By reducing the barriers to business data access and enabling faster, more informed decision-making, SAP HANA Cloud can speed up decision-making and improve overall business effectiveness.

Considering these benefits, IDC calculated that SAP HANA Cloud could enable overall productivity gains of 18%, creating an annual business value of $7.8 million. In the study, one entertainment industry executive summarized how the database delivered value for his company.

entry.title: Introducing Reporting Scope and Data Collection in SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower as of September 1st, 2025.

Why SAP Developed Reporting Scope and Data Collection

SAP introduced the Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature in Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) to address the challenges organizations face when manually collecting sustainability data. Many customers struggled with decentralized, manual processes ‚Äì often relying on emails and spreadsheets ‚Äì which made it difficult to ensure data quality, traceability, and compliance with regulatory requirements. The new feature provides an integrated, workflow-based solution that guides users through the process, ensures relevant KPIs are collected, and supports collaboration between central and local teams. 

What Does the Feature Do?

The Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature enables organizations to:

  • Define which sustainability metrics are relevant for reporting.
  • Configure how data should be collected and who is responsible.
  • Guide users through a structured, form-based workflow for data entry, review, and approval.
  • Track and manage data collection runs for different reporting periods.
  • Ensure data is captured, approved, and stored in a traceable manner. 

Step-by-Step Guide: SAP SCT Applications

  1. Manage Reporting Scope
  • Define the scope of sustainability reporting by selecting relevant metrics and organizational boundaries.
  • Set validity dates and add comments for each metric (e.g., materiality, monitoring purposes).
  • Capture the results of double materiality assessments and specify which KPIs require data collection.
  • In this simplified example the organizational boundary is set to Business Region EMEA and the Scope Items are the ESRS items Total energy consumption related to own operations - E1-5 - (37)(AR 35) and Total water consumption - E3-4 - (28a).

  1. Configure Data Collection
  • Assign data processors and approvers for each scoped metric and organizational entity.
  • Choose the data collection method (e.g., workflow-based).
  • Ensure responsibilities are clear for each data point to streamline collaboration

  1. Configure Data Entry
  • Customize the data entry form for each metric, including the data collection cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly or yearly) and required breakdowns by a master data dimension.
  • Add instructions and enable relevant dimensions to guide processors during data entry

  1. Manage Data Collection Instances
  • Set up data collection runs for specific reporting years and periods.
  • Define start, submission, and approval dates to control the workflow timeline.
  • Generate forms for each reporting period and metric, ensuring timely data collection. 

  1. Manage Data Collection Forms
  • Preview and send out data collection forms to assigned processors.
  • Processors enter data and submit for approval; approvers review, approve, or reject submissions.
  • Approved data is published and stored, with full traceability in SCT. 

 

This new workflow-based approach in SAP SCT streamlines sustainability data collection, improves data quality, and supports compliance with evolving regulatory standards.

Feature status and outlook: Currently, the feature supports quantitative metrics and measures for sustainability reporting. In future iterations, SAP plans to include qualitative metrics and basic custom metrics, as well as additional data entry methods, plausibility checks, multi-step approvals and email notifications based on customer feedback.

For further support, please also visit Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics | SAP Help Portal.
